title.rendered: Charles Schwab – Tips for Smart Investing

content.rendered: The New York Times’ T-Brand Studio client services division took on a mult-phase project with Charles Schwab for their Intelligent Portfolios campaign in the Fall of 2015. The deliverables were distinct experiences for handheld, tablet and desktop with Section 508 Web Accessibility AA Compliance. The first phase was a front-end build with two videos produced by the studio and a few charts.  Phase two, completed in June 2016  involved the addition of Interactive Data visualizations using jQueryUI sliders to manipulate the high charts. For 2017, Phase 3 included a data refresh for all IDVs and new brand new mobile experiences for Fees and Diversification.

title.rendered: United Nations – Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict

content.rendered:
For 13 Years, Powersimple proudly developed and managed the United Nations’ Children and Armed Conflict website, serving under three Under Secretary-Generals.

In 2001, the General Assembly issued a mandate that websites be made available in all six official languages, which was both cost prohibitive and technically complex.  By 2005, Powersimple provided the small modestly-budgeted office with the UN’s first content managed 6 language sites that allowed direct navigation between the same page in all languages. At the time, their platform only supported static html sites which were downloaded via zip and posted manually to separate language accounts. In 2012, Powersimple was the first to develop and deploy a six language site in WordPress, which remained live well into 2018.

The 2012 update to the site included a highly dynamic and sophisticated six language document library, that allowed users to instantly filter by document type, UN Body, year and country.  A six-language interactive map used The Office’s Annual Report data let users browse through the reports by country.

Thanks to the “Way Back Machine”, the internet archive allows you to browse through the history of the site.
